Award.AwardTitle: CRII: Cyberlearning: Keeping Computer Programming Learners Engaged Online

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research aims to create innovative software to broaden access to free online programming education. As computing continues to be increasingly important in the 21st century, more people are turning to discretionary online resources to learn related skills such as computer programming. These resources are great tools to teach the public in large numbers, which is important for economic development and innovation. However, many of these resources struggle to keep their users engaged, which is a critical component for learning. Building interactive systems that can detect users' disengagement and adapt to their needs will become increasingly important in teaching the next generation of learners. Access to these types of free, customized learning experiences will benefit everyone, but especially those in underrepresented groups and/or those living in rural or low income areas, who might not have quality computing education resources available to them otherwise.

This project builds on Gidget, an online educational learning tool designed to teach novices introductory computer programming concepts through debugging puzzles. This project aims to integrate predictors into the tool that can detect struggling and disengaged learners, so that appropriate action(s) can be taken to help them. The curriculum generator component will produce and deliver customized levels to provide struggling learners more practice with concepts they are having difficulty with. The reengage component will produce and display just in time feedback to help reengage disengaged learners. This research will shed new insights into the effectiveness of these techniques on learners' engagement (operationalized as total time spent using the tool and total number of concepts completed) and learning outcomes (determined by a pre-post test of knowledge) in an online educational programming tool, and inform the design of other interactive educational tools. This work contributes to the fields of computing education, interactive educational tools, human-computer interaction, intelligent tutoring systems, and learning science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
More people are increasingly turning to online discretionary resources to learn computer programming/coding and other computing skills. However, little is known about how to keep these online learners engaged with the content and/or activities. Keeping learners engaged with the experience is essential, as the experience may leave a long-lasting impression about whether or not they enjoy the subject. This project investigated how to use various metrics of past and current learners' data in an online educational programming tutorial/application to provide interventions to keep them motivated with the activity.

Across the three years of the project, we made several discoveries. For example, we found specific user behaviors, such as account activation and help-seeking, were good predictors of how many levels/concepts a leaner would complete/learn before quitting the application. We also found that a coarse-grained frustration detector (i.e., modeling frustration by catching actions with major deviations from baseline averages) consistently and accurately recognized learners' disengagement. We used this frustration detector to provide learners with interventions designed to re-engage them with the content. This included a customized message/hint from the system, and/or additional levels covering the same concept. We found that these customized messages had a significant effect keeping learners engaged with the content, and that the additional levels provided additional practice that helped learners succeed in subsequent levels. Moreover, we found that on-demand hints were useful to learners, and that in such cases, animated hints were more helpful than static textual hints. This work also led to new discoveries in computer science (CS) leaners' preferences in learning CS from in-person courses versus automated online tutoring systems, and what factors contribute to increased learner autonomy. We applied these discoveries into the educational application, testing it with online users and with local students, and found that these new features significantly increased learners' engagement with learning online on their own. These results set a clear agenda for future designers of online coding applications and tutorials. They also provide a scientific foundation for designing future learning technologies for teaching many types of computing skills while keeping users engaged. These technologies will be increasingly important as more American jobs begin to require computing skills, demanding rapid and effective learning.

In addition to these scientific contributions, the project had many direct impacts on society. All of these discoveries were incorporated into the freely available online coding tutorial called Gidget (helpgidget.org), which tens of thousands of people have played. This game attracts players from all over the world (with the large majority coming from the USA), and has been shown to be effective in attracting and engaging people of all genders and ages. The project also helped to establish partnerships with local partners, including a non-profit and public-school system. The project ran several coding programs/camps, especially for middle school youth. The project also engaged students in mentorship (12 undergraduate students), software development (2 undergraduate students), and research (2 master students and 3 PhD students).
